unicode.value: Practical Stata
Jim Tyson
face to face

This course is delivered in two parts:

  • Pre-classroom learning consists of video and print materials hosted in the Moodle virtual learning environment and studied independently
  • The half-day classroom session consists of a practical challenge workshop to consolidate the material covered in the pre-learning and provide opportunity for reflection, investigation of issues and questions
Practical Stata Home

University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.

Free Text

In the following learning package some topics contain a link to a video that explains some Stata functionality, guidance on Stata commands and functions and perhaps PDF material to read.  For some topics there may also be activities for you to explore on your own, quizzes that give instant feedback and exercises for you to practise using Stata.

Before attending the classroom Stata session, you must complete all the topics.  You will also find it useful to take notes.

If in completing a topic you create a script, you should ensure that you put commentary in the script so that you can understand it later.

You can use stata on UCL managed machines in public spaces or on the UCL remote desktop when you have an internet connection.  You do not need to download or install Stata to complete this learning.

You navigate topics using the expandable tree to the left of the content.
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

Aim:

To be able to undertake elementary data management and statistical analyses in Stata

Objectives:

After taking this course you will be able to

  • Identify major elements of the Stata interface
  • Import data in some common formats
  • Compute new variables
  • Add labels to a dataset to make it self-documenting
  • Recode variables and derive new variables from existing ones
  • Produce summary statistics, tables and graphs
  • Find online help about a given topic or command
  • Keep a record of you work and ensure it is reproducible
Are you ready to go?
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Pre-requisite knowledge

This course assumes that you have some knowledge and skills before you start.  For example, it assumes that you know some statistics:

  • descriptive statistics such as measures of
    • location
    • dispersion
    • shape
  • the use of graphs and plots
  • the different kinds of data that are analysed statistically such as
    • continuous versus discrete data
    • ordinal versus ration data (and the other levels of measurement)
  • an understanding of hypothesis testing, significance and confidence intervals

Digital Capabilities

It also assumes that you have basic computing skills such as file management and using a text editor or word processing program.

Learning online

The course also assumes that you are comfortable with online learning.  What previous experience of online learning do you have?  How did you find any previous online learning experiences?  Did you enjoy them?  What are the challenges of on-line learning for you and what are the advantages?

Ready to go?

Take a moment to think about the objectives of the course and some of the assumptions outlined above.  Do you understand the objectives and do they correspond to what you want from the course? Do you have the kind of pre-knowledge that the course assumes?
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).

The objectives of this topic are to become familiar with the Stata interface so as to be able to enter Stata commands, identify and examine variables and values and use the review window to access the command history.

Each of these elements is important in using Stata, even if - as is often the case - you go on to do most of your work by writing scripts to automate processes.

The essential activity in this topic is watching the video material.

Using the documents attached below from Stata's help, load the data set results.dta which is stored on the website

http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim

You will need to understand the commands webuse set and webuse.

Webuse set is used to tell Stata to use a specific url (web address) as the source of data files.

Webuse is used to download a data file from a website in to Stata memory.

The first command therefor, is followed by the website address.  The second command is followed by the name of the datafile.

A full description of each command is found the manual links below.

The objective of this topic is to learn to import datasets created in applications other than stata, such as spreadsheets, whether focally or from a remote source.

Loading data from remote sources is a useful technique and can be part of a strategy to treat data as read only.

The essential activity in this topic is watching the video material and then completing the activity to download a data set from a remote source.

Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Please watch this video which explains how you can import data from an Excel spreadsheet.

There are two Stata commands for importing data that you should make yourself familiar with: import excel and import delimited.

Here, they get very brief descriptions but they are described fully in the Stata help and documentation.

Import Excel

This command reads data from an excel spreadsheet.  The general form of the command is

import excel using filename.xlsx, sheet(sheetname) first clear

The option sheet allows you to specify a particular worksheet in the Excel file, otherwise the first sheet in the workbook is imported.  The option first treats the first row of the sheet as variable names and clear removes any data currently in memory.

Import Delimited

This command reads data from plain text files with one case per line and variables separated by some specified delimiter (such as a comma or a tab).  The general form of the command is

import delimited using filename.txt, delimiters(",") varnames(1) clear

The option delimiters tells Stata what character separates variables.  The option varnames tells Stata which row number the variable names are in and clear removes any data currently in memory.

Importing data from the net

Both versions of the import command can be used to import data from a url (a web address).  For example the command

import excel "http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim/results.xls", first clear

Will import an excel data set a UCL personal website. You can try out this command.

Why clear?

Stata can only have one set of variables - that is one data file - in memory at a time.  Therefore, when importing data we use the option clear at the end of the command to make sure that any data currently in memory is removed before the import.

Saving data

The command to save the data currently in memory is save filename.  This command saves in Stata format.

If the dataset already exists with that filename then you will need to add the replace option so the command becomes

save filename, replace

In the data analysis process we should always try to treat data as read only - this means that in each analysis session we download an original data set and perform any data manipulation and modification required in memory then process and analyse the data.  We try not to create a new file containing modified data - after all it is unnecessary.

Below we have attached a data file in Excel format.

The file is named MedicalXtrial.xlsx.

Import this file into Stata.  The first row contains headers.  There are six variables:

patient gender surname age postcode income smoker hbefore hafter

Once you have imported the data

  • examine the data using the data browser (check the last section of this manual page).

Here is what each of these variables measures or records

patient gender surname age postcode income smoker hbefore hafter
Anonymised ID M or F Patient's Surname Age in years Patient's home postcode Income in pounds sterling Y or N Plasma concentration in pg/ml of a specific hormone before treatment Plasma concentration in pg/ml of a specific hormone after treatment

Stata Syntax
Learning in this topic
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

The objective of this topic is to learn the basic, general syntax of Stata commands - what all commands will have in common.

Getting the format of basic commands under your belt will make using Stata more pleasurable and much faster.  In particular you should notice that a command has the general form:

command variable variable...variable, options

That is the variables passed to the command appear as a list separated by spaces and a comma precedes the list of options.

The essential activity in this topic is watching the video material and then working through the UCLA web page in Overview of Stata Syntax.

To try the example code in this topic, you will need to read the file results.xlsx from the website http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim/results.xls
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

We call the structure of a Stata command the Stata syntax borrowing a term from grammar and computer programming.  The resources in this section will help you understand the common structure of Stata commands and show you examples of specific useful commands.

Some of the most common commands are those that operate on variables.  Their general form is

command varlist , options

The elements are varlist are variable names which are separated by spaces.  The options follow a single comma and are specified in the help for each command.

So

summarize maths english, detail

provides detailed summary statistics for the variables maths and english.

Often you can use the bysort command to group output by factors.  For example

bysort sex: summarize maths, detail

(There is also a by prefix command but to use it you must first sort by factor).

One command you need to start using right away is list.  List displays selections from the data in memory.  The bare list will show all variables for all cases.  But you can specify which variables to display in the varlist and you can use the if option to make selections of cases.

So you can

list surname maths, if maths>100

for example.

Try the following command

list in 1/5

Please watch this video which explains the syntax of Stata commands.

Do Files and Log Files

The objective of this topic is to learn about two non-data filetypes

  • do files
  • log files

You will understand how to create each and what their proper uses are and you will be able to summarize the advantages of using a do file over working interactively at the command line.

The essential activities in this topic are watching the video and trying out the do file example code below.

Free Text

The do file

Do files provide a simple way to batch together Stata commands and to automate Stata procedures.  A do file is a simple text file that contains Stata commands, usually one to a line, and possibly simple programming constructs such as loops (to repeat actions) and conditionals (to make decisions or selections).

It is very convenient to work on the Stata command line, but there are also advantages to creating do files, especially for more complicated procedures.  Using a do file

  • helps you create work is reproducible
  • makes it much  easier to check and debug your procedures  than by scrolling through your command history
  • if you create a do file that does the data preparation and the analysis, you are sure that you are always starting with the correct data

Please watch  this video to learn about Stata scripting with Do Files.

This pdf gives some good basic advice about creating and using do files.
Stata Manual Page: creating do files
Toughra Technologies FZ LLC.

The log file

A log file is an automatically created record of the input and output of a stata session.  It comtains the commands you have issued to Stata and Stata's responses.  There are two formats for log smcl (pronounced smickle) and plain text.  SMCL is a rich mark up format that can be used by sophisticated users to produce nicely formatted output.  In general, a plain text log file is adequate.

You start a log file at any time with the command

log using "filename_for_my_log", text

and you close and save with the command

log close

which will also save the file.

A log file is a useful record of what you do in a session.  I strongly recommend that logfiles should have names including the project name and the date of the Stata session.  If you regularly use a standard format for log file names you will make your life much easier.
Try out a do file

Generating Variables
Learning in this topic
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

The objective of this topic is to learn about creating new variables in Stata.  You might create a variable for a number of reasons.  For example,

  • as a row aggregate - for example an average of several temperature measures for each patient in your study
  • as a transformation of an existing variable - for example taking the log of a variable to mitigate the effect of skewness
  • as a sub-setting action on an existing variable - for instance dividing subjects into groups low, mid and high based on an existing numeric income score

The essential activities in this topic are reading the explanations of gen and egen and then carrying out the activity Generating a continuous and a ranked variable.
.
Free Text

Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Please watch this video.

gen

The gen command (shortened form of generate) can be used to create a new variable with

  • missing values
    gen newvar = .
  • a specific value
    gen newvar = 0
  • a calculated value
    gen newvar = (oldvar1 + oldvar)/oldvar3
    (almost any mathematical expression)

So using the data from results.dta we could use the command

gen avxm=(maths+english+history)/3

to generate a new variable containing the average of the three examination scores in the dataset.

egen

The egen provides some extensions to generate.  The complete functionality can be found in the egen help but here is the code that produces the average exam score again, using egen

egen avxm=rowmean(maths english history)

One useful variation on egen is to use it with the options cut and icodes. Suppose that having created avxm we want to assign cases to grades with the following rule:

avxm=0 to avxm<50 go into grade = 0
avxm>=50 to avxm<60 go into grade = 1
avxm>=60 to avxm=100 go into grade 2

the code to do this is

egen grade = cut(avxm), at(0 50 60 101) icodes

The last value in the option at() must be greater than the highest value in the data (or rather, possible in the data).  The option icodes gives each level of the resulting variable grade an integer value.  Without icodes the new variable would have as its value the left margin of each range.
Generating a continuous and a ranked variable

Labelling variables and values
Learning in this topic
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

The essential activity in this topic is watching the video linked below.

The objectives of this topic are to explain how both variables and values can be labelled.  A variable in a dataset may have a name that isn't very human friendly and while we would not normally want to change the name (it may for example be the standard for a well known data set or family of data sets) nonetheless it is helpful if we can use a friendly name in output such as tables and graphs.  A value for some variable may also be labelled.  For example, we may have a variable that ranks cases based on the intervals into which the scores fall.  We might wish to label these intervales, perhaps low, mid and high.
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Labels

Please watch this video.

You can label a variable or its values (if they are discrete).

If for example you have questionnaire data, you may have variables named

q1, q2,...,q100

This is convenient in some respects but it is obviously difficult to remember the actual content of each of these.  It makes sense to label the variables with the actual wording of the questions.

Similarly it is useful to have human friendly labels for the discrete levels of categorical variables so that if a variable control had values 0 and 1 we could label them treatment and control.

Labelling a variable

You can label a variable with the command

label variable "I chose this label"

Define a label set for values

A factor variable is a categorical variable (nominal or ordinal).  As we saw when the bysort prefix command was introduced, factors can be used to group cases of data.  For example, the factor sex may divide your data into a number of subsets.

Often, factors are encoded as numbers, 1/2 for male or female or 0/1 for yes or no.  Often it is convenient to have a human friendly label for these factor levels.  We create labels with

label define labelsetname value label...value label

For example

label define classes 1 "First Class" 2 "Second Class" 3 "Third Class"

This creates a new set of labels called classes such that a case with value 1 will be labelled First Class, 2 Second Class and 3 Third Class.  This set of labels can now be applied to any factor variable - nominal or ordinal - with three levels and numeric values 1,2 and 3.

Apply a label set to variable values

The label set is applied to the values of a factor with the following command

label values variable labelsetname

For example

label values class classes

Be prepared!

Before analysing data you will want to be sure that so far as possible the raw data is free from errors and not corrupted.  The process of preparing data for anaysis is often called data cleaning.  The material in this topic introduces some of the basic things you can do in Stata to clean data.

Please watch this video.

You may find the Wikipedia article on data cleaning useful.

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Data preparation and do files

Let's imagine a fairly typical data analysis task.  Imagine that your work involves analysing the most recent British Labour Force Survey data from ONS.  The task goes like this:

  1. download the latest, most up to date data set
  2. drop the variables you don't need
  3. check that all remaining variable values are in range and produce a report on any out of range values or drop cases with out of range data (this is of course a theoretical problem that you have to work out...)
  4. create derived variables
    1. aggregates - maybe averages of existing scores
    2. rankings - creating some ordinal values from existing continuous variables
    3. create some basic plots and summaries

It is of course possible that you could decide to download the data just once at the start of your study, save it locally and work on that version from then on, but this isn't always the best approach.

If you do want to always have the most up to date version of the data, then you don't want to do the tasks above manually each time.  So it makes sense to create a do file.  To create that file I suggest making an outline of the tasks like the one above and then copying it to your do file as comment.  There is a partial example attached below that you can look at.  Not all the code is fully explained so you will need to do some research if you want to understand it before the classroom session.
File Attachments
Toughra Technologies FZ LLC.
File Attachments Idevice.
This is the text of a partial do file for a data preparation task.  If you wanted to use this in Stata you would rename it to have a .do extension.
Dealing with a data type issue
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Sometimes when you import data into Stata, you will find that the data type is not what you expect.  The data values you observe may look like numbers, but the data may in fact have been imported as a string.

Since many operations will be senstive to the distinction if any variable is incorrectly marked as a string you will need to correct that.

Using the stata help and any other resources you have, find the stata command that would convert a string variable to a numeric variable.

What do you think might be the most important advice you could give someone on using the command?
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).

The command that will convert a variable from string type to numeric type is destring.

It is useful when data appears to be numeric - ie the characters are all in the range 0-9 - but the type is recognised by stata as str.  If you look at the manual page you will see that it has options to replace existing values or generate new variables.

The best advice to give is that before using destring you should copy the existing variable (or indeed the data set) or that you should use destring with the generate option.  Be aware that if you have do files working on the variable, then using destring may cause them to fail or create anomalous results.

The command that will convert a variable from string type to numeric type is destring.

It is useful when data appears to be numeric - ie the characters are all in the range 0-9 - but the type is recognised by stata as str.  If you look at the manual page you will see that it has options to replace existing values or generate new variables.

The best advice to give is that before using destring you should copy the existing variable (or indeed the data set) or that you should use destring with the generate option.  Be aware that if you have do files working on the variable, then using destring may cause them to fail or create anomalous results.
Summary statistics: tabstat
Learning in this topic
University of Auckland

Type the learning objectives for this resource.
The objective in this topic is to explain the use of the Stata command tabstat for producing summary statistics.
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Please watch this video which explains the use of the tabstat command.

The tabstat command takes the general form

tabstat variable, statistics(...) by(factor)

With tabstat the following statistics are available

mean

mean

count

count of nonmissing observations

n

same as count

sum

sum

max

maximum

min

minimum

range

range = max - min

sd

standard deviation

variance

variance

cv

coefficient of variation (sd/mean)

semean

standard error of mean (sd/sqrt(n))

skewness

skewness

kurtosis

kurtosis

p1

1st percentile

p5

5th percentile

p10

10th percentile

p25

25th percentile

median

median (same as p50)

p50

50th percentile (same as median)

p75

75th percentile

p90

90th percentile

p95

95th percentile

p99

99th percentile

iqr

interquartile range = p75 - p25

q

equivalent to specifying p25 p50 p75
Tabstat (and understanding code)
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Create a file with the following code lines.

import excel "http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim/results.xls", clear first case(lower)

gen avxm=(maths+english+history)/3

local conts maths english history avxm

format `conts' %9.2f

tabstat `conts', statistics(mean, var, sd) by(sex)

Run the code and then comment each line explaining what it does.  Use the Stata help or any other resource to help you explain the code.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).

*import data from an excel spreadhsheet, clear data from memory first, and put variable names from the first row in lower case

import excel "http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim/results.xls", clear first case(lower)

*create a new variable avmx which is the average of the three exam scores

gen avxm=(maths+english+history)/3

*create a local macro (name) to refer to all the continuous variables conveniently

local conts maths english history avxm

*specify that the continuous variable output should be displayed to two decimal places

format `conts' %9.2f

*show a table of the mean, variance and standard deviation for all the continuous variables split by sex

tabstat `conts', statistics(mean, var, sd) by(sex)

*import data from an excel spreadhsheet, clear data from memory first, and put variable names from the first row in lower case

import excel "http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~ccaajim/results.xls", clear first case(lower)

*create a new variable avmx which is the average of the three exam scores

gen avxm=(maths+english+history)/3

*create a local macro (name) to refer to all the continuous variables conveniently

local conts maths english history avxm

*specify that the continuous variable output should be displayed to two decimal places

format `conts' %9.2f

*show a table of the mean, variance and standard deviation for all the continuous variables split by sex

tabstat `conts', statistics(mean, var, sd) by(sex)

Exploring Data
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Now, please work through this web page about exploring data.

As you study the page, you should try out the commands discussed using the data set which you can download by issuing the command at the start of the notes:

use http://www.ats.ucla.edu/stat/data/hs0, clear

You may find it a useful exercise to create a do file containing the commands and experiment with running it.
The Class Room Session
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Congratulations

You have now completed the pre-learning for the Practical Stata course.

When you come to the classroom session, we will assume that you have completed this work.

The class room session involves work on a data set involving writing a data preparation do file; managing data; describing and exploring data; hypothesis testing and regression modelling.

Next steps

The classroom session will involve a range of statistical skills to be used in Stata.  You are not expected to have the Stata knowledge in advance of the classroom session but you are expected to have the knowledge of statistics.

Topics you will need to have covered before attending include:

Descriptive statistics

  • mean
  • median
  • mode
  • variance
  • standard deviation
  • correlation

Inferential statiistics

  • t-tests (independent and paired)
  • chi-square test
  • linear regression

You will not be able to follow that session if you do not have this statistical knowledge.

Outline

The material to be covered includes:

  • The Stata program environment
  • Entering data
  • Browsing data
  • Editing data
  • Describing data
  • Computing values
  • Simple recoding
  • Simple descriptive statistics
  • Recoding values
  • Simple hypothesis testing
  • Producing basic plots

Prerequisites

General

Attendees should have a good understanding of basic statistics.

Pre-learning

Before attending the classroom session, participants must complete the material indicated below.
Jim Tyson

This course is delivered in two parts:

  • Pre-classroom learning consists of video and print materials hosted in the Moodle virtual learning environment and studied independently
  • The half-day classroom session consists of a practical challenge workshop to consolidate the material covered in the pre-learning and provide opportunity for reflection, investigation of issues and questions
